t: Proverbs 29
Whoever*pn remains stiff-necked after many rebukes will*ld suddenly be destroyed—without remedy.
When*pn the righteous thrive, the people rejoice; when*ld the wicked rule, the people groan.
A*pn man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father, but*ld a companion of prostitutes squanders his wealth.
By*pn justice a king gives a country stability, but*ld those who are greedy for bribes tear it down.
Those*pn who flatter their neighbors are*ld spreading nets for their feet.
Evildoers*pn are snared by their own sin, but*ld the righteous shout for joy and are glad.
The*pn righteous care about justice for the poor, but*ld the wicked have no such concern.
Mockers*pn stir up a city, but*ld the wise turn away anger.
If*pn a wise person goes to court with a fool, the*ld fool rages and scoffs, and there is no peace.
The*pn bloodthirsty hate a person of integrity and*ld seek to kill the upright.
Fools*pn give full vent to their rage, but*ld the wise bring calm in the end.
If*pn a ruler listens to lies, all*ld his officials become wicked.
The*pn poor and the oppressor have this in common: The*ld Lord*s gives sight to the eyes of both.
If*pn a king judges the poor with fairness, his*ld throne will be established forever.
A*pn rod and a reprimand impart wisdom, but*ld a child left undisciplined disgraces its mother.
When*pn the wicked thrive, so does sin, but*ld the righteous will see their downfall.
Discipline*pn your children, and they will give you peace; they*ld will bring you the delights you desire.
Where*pn there is no revelation, people cast off restraint; but*ld blessed is the one who heeds wisdom’s instruction.
Servants*pn cannot be corrected by mere words; though*ld they understand, they will not respond.
Do*pn you see someone who speaks in haste? There*ld is more hope for a fool than for them.
A*pn servant pampered from youth will*ld turn out to be insolent.
An*pn angry person stirs up conflict, and*ld a hot-tempered person commits many sins.
Pride*pn brings a person low, but*ld the lowly in spirit gain honor.
The*pn accomplices of thieves are their own enemies; they*ld are put under oath and dare not testify.
Fear*pn of man will prove to be a snare, but*ld whoever trusts in the Lord*s is kept safe.
Many*pn seek an audience with a ruler, but*ld it is from the Lord*s that one gets justice.
The*pn righteous detest the dishonest; the*ld wicked detest the upright.
